title: Seedling
text: While Europe is in its Early Middle Ages (AD 614-911), a redwood seedling sprouts in a quiet grove in Northern California.

title: Messenger Birds
text: Pigeon post was the world’s fastest communication system for all the centuries of the Dark and Middle ages.

title: Printing Press
text: The first European printing technology is credited to the German printer Johannes Gutenberg in 1450.

title: Shakespeare
text: Shakespeare writes Romeo and Juliet. During the height of the Renaissance in Europe, the redwood tree is already almost 900 years old.

title: Pacific Coast
text: The Cascadia earthquake rocks the Pacific Northwest sending a tsunami to the coast of Japan. During this time an estimated 2,100,000 acres along coastal California are quietly populated with redwood trees.

title: Gold Rush
text: The mines that burgeoned during the gold rush and the towns that supported them had a voracious appetite for timber, including redwood trees. This is when many California forests began to disappear.

title: Computer Era
text: Development of electronic computers began in the 1950’s. In 1982, the concept of a world-wide network of interconnected computers, called the Internet, was introduced. The Internet was commercialized in 1995.

title: 21st Century
text: As we enter 2014, the Internet is part of daily life, and computers are the size of a smart phone. It’s estimated that only 5% or less of the original old-growth trees still exist, with most residing in protected state parks.
